passages.text: JPMC Construction Dail

- Eiffage: Model Update. We update our model following Eiffage's H1 results (link to our first take). Our 25E EBIT decreases slightly as we increase our estimate for the Holding level loss, with our Contracting EBIT increasing and Concessions EBIT very slightly decreasing. We also incorporate revised guidance for the impact of France's surtax in 2025, underpinning the increase in our 25E Net Income. Our Dec-26 PT is unchanged at â‚¬136, now implying 25% upside to the current share price, despite our increased estimates as we MTM in our WACC for interest rates. Link to our report.

- Vinci reports July toll road traffic at \(+1\%\) y/y and airport traffic at \(+3.6\%\) y/y. Vinci released its July traffic report for toll roads and airports after market close yesterday. For autoroutes, Vinci reported a \(+1\%\) increase y/y (vs \(+2.3\%\) in Q2). The growth was driven by light vehicle (LV) traffic at \(+1\%\) y/y in July (vs \(+2.7\%\) in Q2), while heavy vehicles (HV) were \(+0.4\%\) y/y (vs \(-0.4\%\) in Q2). Overall, YTD, traffic levels have risen by \(2.2\%\) for LV, \(0.5\%\) for HV and \(2\%\) for total traffic. In the airport sector, Vinci reported continuous positive trends in July, at \(+3.6\%\) y/y (vs \(+5.1\%\) in June). Traffic at ANA stood at \(+5.2\%\) y/y (vs \(+5.9\%\) in June). Similarly, OMA saw positive y/y trends with \(7.7\%\) growth (vs \(+9.2\%\) in June), while traffic in France was up \(1.6\%\) y/y (vs \(+2.4\%\) in June). UK traffic stood at \(+0.3\%\) y/y (-0.2\%\) in June). The US experienced a decline in traffic at \(-10\%\) y/y (vs -8.1% in June). Link to the press release.

- Amrize recommends shareholders reject mini-tender offer by TRC Capital Investment Corporation. Amrize has received a notice of an unsolicited "mini-tender" offer by TRC Capital Investment Corporation to purchase up to 2,000,000 ordinary shares of Amrize at a price of \(49.63\). The offer represents less than \(1.0\%\) of the outstanding Ordinary Shares. TRC's offer price is \(4.48\%\) less than the \(51.96\) closing price on August 26, 2025, the last trading day before the mini-tender offer commenced. Amrize does not endorse TRC's unsolicited mini-tender offer and recommends that Amrize shareholders do not tender their Ordinary Shares in the offer because the offer is at a price below the current market price for the Ordinary Shares. TRC has included in the terms of its offer a condition that the closing price of the Ordinary Shares must not decrease by more than \(5\%\) from the closing price on August 26, 2025. As a result, unless TRC decides to waive this condition, Amrize shareholders who tender their Ordinary Shares in the offer would receive a below-market price for Amrize's Ordinary Shares through the tender offer. The offer is also subject to numerous other conditions. Link to the press release.

- Divinereach acquires \(25\%\) stake in Dyckerhoff Ukraine from CRH. Global Cement reports (link) that Divinereach, a company led by Hyundai Ireland chair Eugene O'Reilly, has bought a \(25\%\) stake in Dyckerhoff Ukraine from CRH, according to Business Post Ireland. The sale was a condition of CRH's 2024 acquisition of Dyckerhoff from Italy-based Buzzi.
European Building & Construction and Infrastructure

- Ash Grove trials Boston Dynamics robot for kiln and plant safety. Global Cement reports (link) that Ash Grove Cement, part of CRH, has deployed Boston Dynamics' autonomous robot 'Spot' at its cement plant in Washington in a year-long pilot to boost efficiency and safety. Operating more than 80 hours a week, the four-legged robot conducts routine inspections using a 4K camera and laser scanning, detecting anomalies and alerting teams before failures occur.

- French politics: Scenarios and implications for the macro, rates and FX outlook. The J.P.Morgan France Economics and Policy Research team believe that the Bayrou government is likely to fall in September. Fiscal outcomes overall would be in line with the team's deficit forecast (5.3% next year, 5.5% this year; consensus is similar), so the fiscal consolidation would be significantly less than assumed by the Bayrou government. If the new PM option is politically unstable, Macron could call a snap election. The most likely outcome would be a relative majority RN government. This political outcome would be unstable but the fiscal implications would remain in line with the team's forecast. Link to the team's report.

- US Homebuilding: July Pending Home Sales Roughly Flat, In-Line w/ Street's Outlook. The J.P.Morgan US Housebuilding Research team notes that the July Pending Home Sales Index - which represents homes entered into contract, not closings - fell 0.4% sequentially to 71.7, roughly in-line with the Street's outlook for a 0.2% decline to 71.8. Additionally, on a YOY basis, July pending home sales rose 0.7%, which follows last month's 2.8% decline. Other recent housing data points also reflect similar trends, including the August NAHB survey down 1 points seq. and 18% YOY, July existing home sales up 2% seq. and 1% YOY, July new home sales down 1% seq. and 8% YOY and July housing starts up 5% seq. and 13% YOY. Link to the team's report.

- Skanska invests CZK 1.2bn, about SEK 540m, in the third phase of a residential project in Prague, Czech Republic. The construction contract is worth CZK 898M, about SEK 400m, which will be included in the order bookings for Europe for the third quarter of 2025. This phase will feature 132 low-energy apartments spread across four buildings. Comprising about 800 housing units in total, the project is to be delivered in six phases. The construction of the third phase starts in August 2025 and is scheduled for completion in 2028. Readaross for Vinci, Eiffage and Ferrovial. Link to the press release.

- SPIE: Intelligent traffic management system enhances motorway safety in Austria. As a member of an international consortium, even, a company of SPIE Germany Switzerland Austria and a specialist in automated control systems, was awarded the contract by ASFINAG in 2018. As part of this consortium, even developed the system's intuitive graphical user interface based on its proprietary software platform, even XAMControl. The new interface enables unified control and management of traffic technology infrastructure from all ASFINAG traffic management centres. Tunnel systems, emergency call systems, traffic signs, lighting controls and monitoring equipment can now be managed quickly and efficiently. In total, the new VMIS integrates more than 33,000 connected traffic units and about six million interacting data points into one centralised system across a motorway network spanning more than 2,200 kilometres. Readaross for Vinci and Eiffage. Link to the press release.

- West China Cement increases sales by 24% in 1H25. Cement reports (link) that West China Cement Ltd has announced a strong financial performance for the first half of 2025, marked by substantial growth in sales, revenue, and profitability. Cement and clinker sales volumes increased by 23.6%, while aggregates sales volumes rose by 39.4%. This uplift supported a 46.4% rise in revenue. Gross profit surged by 67.2%, while profit attributable to owners nearly doubled, up 93.4% year on year. Although the EBITDA margin edged down slightly, gross profit margins improved significantly, underscoring the company's efficiency and resilience.
- Martin Engineering launches updated railcar opener. Global Cement reports (link)

that Martin Engineering has launched its two- wheeled Maint Gen 4 Railcar Opener. It is designed to aid bulk handlers to unload processed and processed bulk materials from rail transport to facilities, including cement plants and terminals. The fourth generation product is intended to improve ease of use and reduce potential hazards for workers.

- UK tests revive fly ash for low-carbon cement. Cement reports (link) that pilot plant trials led by the UK Quality Ash Association (UKQAA) have shown that coal-derived fly ash (CDFA) can be successfully processed to meet UK and European standards for use in cement and concrete.
Source: J.P. Morgan estimates, Bloomberg Finance L.P. Infrastructure average excludes Ferrovial. UK Homebuilders are on calendarised estimates. Priced as of COB Aug 28, 2025.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
